args: Why did you bring me here,\n{player_name}?
He's giving a performance this evening.
And we're here to see it?!
Yep. I'm thinking a good way to learn more\nabout music is to observe someone who\ndoes it for a living.
Well, yes, but I could learn more from the\nperformances of other singers.
Vixel may be a successful musician,\nbut he's merely a conductor.
I think ＂merely＂ really downplays his\nachievements. He used to be a member\nof the Choir, right?
Besides, you should probably do more than\njust listen to other singers.
I want you to go to the Halidom and have\nmany different experiences.
Hello there, you two! Have you come to\nlisten to the performance?
That's right—but I also wanted to show\nElias what a conductor's work is like.
Do you mind if we shadow you for a bit?\nWe promise not to get in the way.
Of course. That said, things will be rather\nbusy before the show, so I may not be able\nto pay you much attention.
That's all right. We really appreciate this.
Do you have a moment, maestro?\nI had a question about the coda.
Of course. Let me just look at my score...
Right then. What do you need?
It would be best to perform this particular\npassage in a composed manner, yes?
Indeed. I want you play it as though you\nare plunging the listeners into a dream.
Maestro, do you have a moment? I have a\nquestion about this particular movement.
Vixel is really something, isn't he?\nLook how precisely he's answering\nall of these questions.
Well, sure—but he's still just a conductor.\nAnyone with a modicum of musical skill\ncould do what he's doing.
You really are harsh on Vixel, aren't you?

Not half so much as he deserves! If he's
going to abandon singing, the least he can
do is make sure the audience enjoys what
music he DOES make.
Please play this movement as you like.\nDo as your heart tells you.
Thank you, maestro! I will do just that!
The show is about to begin, maestro.
Let's head to our seats, Elias.
(I can't believe he told that musician to\njust play however he felt was right!\nThis is going to be a disaster...)
Thank you for the performance, Vixel—\nand for indulging us before the show,\nas well.
The gratitude is mine to give.\nBut if I may ask, what did you think?
It was absolutely wonderful!\nDon't you think so, Elias?
Ha ha! I take that as high praise coming\nfrom the two of you. In fact—
You really should be more careful with\nyour score, Vixel. It's impor...
Your music is covered in handwritten\nnotes. Did you make all of these?
Yes. I'm a conductor, after all.\nSuch diligence is all part of the job.
For example, I have to note what kind\nof tone I'd like for a particular phrase,\nor how I ought direct a certain movement.
Interpreting and deepening a piece of\nmusic is a conductor's purview.
Then why did you say what you said?!
You told one of the musicians to just play\nhowever he wanted.
Yet right here, you've made meticulous\nnotes about how you think that section\nshould sound.
Ah, yes. Honestly, it seemed better to\nleave that choice up to the performer.
So that is what I did.
But what if his interpretation was\ncompletely dissonant with the rest\nof the piece?
Isn't it a conductor's duty to make sure\neveryone is on the same page?
Well, yes and no. I don't demand they\nperform in an exacting way so much as\nI...watch over them all.
I told that musician to do as he pleased\nbecause we have rehearsed together for\ncountless hours and I trust his judgment.

Music is not math—there is not always
a single right answer for any situation.
Sometimes it's best to let a musician
trust their emotions.
But you knew how you wanted it to sound!
This is not about me or my ego.\nMy first duty is to the music alone.
I pull and nudge at things when the\nsituation calls for it, but I'm also willing\nto step aside if that's for the best.
A person who can intuitively grasp those\ntwo things will make for a fine conductor.
It would be rather boring if our whole\nchorus always performed in fortissimo, no?
Until now, I always thought the person who\nunderstood the song the best should be\nthe one who guided it along.
I thought their job was to make sure no\none else got lost or made a mistake.
Well, the person who takes up that duty\nIS exceptionally important.
But that's not all there is to it.
One cannot play the greatest music all\non their lonesome.
The greatest music comes from all players\nand parts uniting as a whole.
Would you both excuse me for a moment?\nI need to think about some things.
Heh. Thanks for the lesson, Vixel.
No need to thank me. It would give me\ngreat joy to see him succeed.
He can do it. I know he can.
